Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Watershed Foods, LLC

Gridley, IL

Introduction

A Risk Management Plan has been implemented at the Watershed Foods, LLC facility located at 202 North Ford Street in Gridley, Illinois, for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The Risk Management Plan, will be referred to as the RMP, and will address the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to site personnel, contractors, visitors and the community and environment at large with regards to hazardous chemical releases.  The RMP is organized to correspond with the EPA Risk Management Plan, Program 3 of 40 CFR 68, Subpart G, and Model Risk Management Program for Ammonia Refrigeration.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Watershed Foods, LLC is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and to the environment.  It is Watershed Foods policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations.

This RMP has identified potential hazards and has taken steps to design and maintain a safe facility in order to prevent releases, and minimize the consequences of accidental releases, which could occur.  RMP addresses potentially catastrophic chemical releases that could result in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors, (public and environmental).  Watershed Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Watershed Foods facility is located at 202 North Ford Street in Gridley, IL.  The facility is a supplier of freeze-dried products.  The NAICS code for the facility is 311423.

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration and is

regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule.  There are two (2) refrigeration systems onsite that are used for cold storage and freeze drying processes.

The amount of ammonia present in the Freezer refrigeration system is approximately 8,000 pounds.  The Freezer refrigeration system is a single stage system with three (3) low stage compressors. Air Handling Units and ICM Dashers are fed with pumped liquid from the receiver, through the recirculator.  This system is used to cool the main freezer area, USDA room, Shipping and Receiving Dock, Depositing room and process and the depositing holding area.

The amount of ammonia present in the Freeze Dryer refrigeration system is approximately 17,000 pounds.  The Freeze Dryer system can either be run on low stage or dual stage.  This system consists of two (2) compressors which can either be run on low stage if demand is low or high stage if demand is high.  There is also another low low stage compressor for this system that is used if demand is high.  Dryer Vapor Traps and air handling units in the process areas are fed with pumped liquid from the receivers, through the recirculator.  This system is used to cool 6 dryers, the traying room, hardening room, and Dryer 6 holding and prep area.

The total amount of ammonia onsite between the Freezer and Freeze Dryer refrigeration systems is approximately 25,000 pounds which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

An aerial photo of the site is included as Appendix A.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management Program (PSM standard 29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP standard 40 CFR 68).  The program is reviewed frequently and Watershed Foods actively works at improving this program.

The prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia ab

ove the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules.  The most recent audit of the PSM program occurred between March and November of 2013, with some elements reviewed again between May and September of 2014.  A full review and audit of all elements of both the PSM and RMP programs has been undertaken from February to December of 2015.  These audits are in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every 3 years with a full audit including the Process hazard analysis every 5 years.  The elements of the prevention program are listed as follows.

?    Employee Participation - Watershed Foods has a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures full representation of the various departments and all employees of the facility.  These representatives are included in process reviews and management of change initiatives. These representatives are listed as members of the PSM Committee and meet at a minimum of 3 times per year.  In addition, all employees have access to process hazard analysis and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.

?    Process Safety Information - Watershed Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Watershed Foods has a site specific PHA program that was audited in 2015 and updated according to management of change protocols when applicable.

?    Operating Procedures - Watershed Foods has an updated site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures that they are updated and properly maintained.  Operating procedures are reviewed at least annually and updated as needed when a procedure or process is improved without MOC being involved.

?    Training - Watershed Foods conducts both formal and informal training sessions as regards the process.  Training in documentation has

been conducted with department heads and engineering representatives. Employees will receive training in the potential hazards of the process, the causes of process problems and their specific roles in dealing with these issues.

?    Management of Change (MOC) - Watershed Foods has a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures that changes to the ammonia process (except for changes in kind), such as the addition of new equipment, changes to operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.

?    Pre-Startup Review - Watershed Foods has a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures that a safety review is performed whenever modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require an MOC. 

?    Mechanical Integrity - Watershed Foods has a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures that a preventative maintenance program is in place and is being implemented, documented and that any training related to this program is carried out.

?    Contractors - Watershed Foods has updated the qualifications requirements for the contractors they are expected to use.  In addition to completing an annual training program, they will provide proof of insurance and their OSHA 300 logs to prove their competence in working in hazardous chemical environments.

?    Incident Investigation - Watershed Foods has a site-specific incident investigation procedure that could have resulted in a release of ammonia is investigated in a timely fashion by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

?    Compliance Audit - Compliance audits will be conducted a minimum of every three (3) years to verify that Watershed Foods, LLC PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate, up to date, and are being followed.

?    Hot Work Permits - Watershed Foods, LLC has updated their Hot Work Permit and has a written procedure for the issuance of the permit.

Five (5) Year Accident History

The Watershed Foods facility has not had an accidental ammonia re

lease onsite, or offsite nor have they experienced injuries, forced evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last 5 years.

Emergency Response Program

Watershed Foods, LLC has an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.

Watershed Foods, LLC has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with emergency first responders.  A copy of the emergency action plan is coordinated and shared with both local and county emergency planning commissions.  The local emergency responder is given a plant tour to familiarize their department personnel with the layout of the facility.  Each entity is given a site plan and the hazardous material information used on site.

Watershed Foods, LLC has two (2) windsocks present and maintained onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the facility.

The current Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Any changes to improve safety will be identified as ACTION ITEMS by the auditing committee and acted on in a timely fashion.  These action items will be identified on a form in the audit section.  The responsible person designated to follow the items will report to the PSM Committee during regular scheduled meetings to report the item status.

Management Program

Watershed Foods, LLC has a PSM committee to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  The members are assigned areas of responsibility in line with their qualifications. Members assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If the scope of the process falls outside the capabilities of the individual members, outside consulting hel
p will be procured. Those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through documentation.
